question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Who was Anusuya Chinsamy's employer in 2000?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

Title: Unveiling the Fossil Secrets of South Africa: The Story of Anusuya Chinsamy and Iziko South African Museum

In the heart of Cape Town, South Africa, lies a treasure trove of natural history, the Iziko South African Museum. For decades, this esteemed institution has been a hub for scientific discovery, and one researcher who has made significant contributions to its rich legacy is Anusuya Chinsamy. As we delve into the fascinating world of paleontology, we'll uncover the evidence that supports the claim: Anusuya Chinsamy worked for Iziko South African Museum. Our journey begins in the 1990s, when Anusuya Chinsamy, a young and ambitious researcher, was making a name for herself in the field of paleontology. With a passion for uncovering the secrets of the ancient world, Chinsamy was drawn to the Iziko South African Museum, an institution renowned for its extensive collections of fossils and artifacts. It was here that she would embark on a career that would span decades, leaving an indelible mark on the scientific community. One of Chinsamy's earliest publications, "Dinosaur bone histology: A review" (1995), co-authored with her colleague, John A. Ruben, provides a crucial piece of evidence supporting her affiliation with the Iziko South African Museum. The paper, which explores the significance of bone histology in understanding dinosaur biology, lists Chinsamy's affiliation as the "South African Museum, Cape Town." This early publication not only showcases Chinsamy's expertise in the field but also establishes her connection to the museum. As Chinsamy's career progressed, she continued to make significant contributions to the field of paleontology, often in collaboration with her colleagues at the Iziko South African Museum. A 2002 paper, "Microstructure of dinosaur bone: A review of the evidence" (co-authored with Peter D. Ward), further solidifies her connection to the museum. The paper, which examines the microstructure of dinosaur bones, lists Chinsamy's affiliation as the "Iziko South African Museum, Cape Town." This publication not only demonstrates Chinsamy's ongoing research at the museum but also highlights her growing reputation as a leading expert in the field. Chinsamy's work at the Iziko South African Museum extended beyond research and publication. She was also an active participant in the museum's educational programs, dedicated to sharing her knowledge with the next generation of scientists.
content.source_2: In the year 2024, Dr. Anusuya Chinsamy embarked on a new chapter in her illustrious career as a researcher, joining the esteemed University of Wisconsin–Madison as a faculty member. The campus, nestled in the heart of Madison, Wisconsin, was abuzz with excitement as Chinsamy brought her expertise to the institution. As the years unfolded, Chinsamy's presence at UW–Madison became synonymous with innovation and discovery. Her groundbreaking research in her field drew international attention, and her name became a byword for excellence. The university's state-of-the-art facilities and collaborative environment proved to be the perfect catalyst for her work, and she thrived in the midst of the vibrant academic community. The late 2020s were a time of great transformation, and Chinsamy's work played a significant role in shaping the future. As the world grappled with the challenges of climate change, technological disruption, and shifting global dynamics, her research provided crucial insights that informed policy decisions and inspired new generations of thinkers. In 2028, Chinsamy's team made a seminal breakthrough, publishing a paper that sent shockwaves through the scientific community. The discovery, which had far-reaching implications for sustainable energy solutions, cemented her reputation as a trailblazer and earned her numerous accolades. As the decade drew to a close, Chinsamy's influence extended beyond the university's walls. She became a sought-after speaker on the global circuit, sharing her vision for a better future with audiences from Beijing to Berlin. Her work inspired a new wave of entrepreneurs, policymakers, and activists, who saw in her a beacon of hope for a brighter tomorrow. In 2032, after eight remarkable years at UW–Madison, Chinsamy's tenure came to an end. Though her departure was met with sadness from her colleagues and students, her legacy remained, etched in the very fabric of the institution. The university, forever changed by her presence, continued to thrive, nurturing the next generation of leaders and innovators. As Chinsamy embarked on the next chapter of her journey, the world looked on, eager to see what the future held for this remarkable individual.
